words: So, um, it was...I...I just saw all these classes coming together. You know, I thought that we really had to explore...because, at the time, the movement was the Mestizo, right, the Indian, the Spaniard, and the, ah...the Mestizo here. And I go, ah, it’s not really like that, okay? It’s that...one that might reflect more our self-doubt. Because we are one; we are not divided. A self cannot be divided. A self must be one. If it’s divided it’s in conflict. Okay, are we or aren’t we? And, so we...we really need to go t—into the issue of mis—not just genocide but miscegenation, you know. And we need to go before the Europeans came over and look at, um...first, it was about the (malinche myth 8:30), right? But...so we really have to look at, ah...um, what was going on in Mexico before the Europeans came, and that Mexico was not one. It was multiple nations, and that the Aztecs were as bad as any, ah, tyr—tyrant or tyrannical culture going on in the world. So, ah...and that people were revolting against them. That’s why these few Spanish were able to undermine them then, and they had alliances and they had support.

speaker: But let’s go more into it. Who? Why? What was going on? Who were these different people? Were they, ah, united together or separately and what happened afterwards, you know? Um, s—and then, Ah...and then the deities and the goddesses, how...where are they indigenous? Because they have multiple names in different places, and they have different intonations. And what...what is the story? What’s behind this story? Who are...you know, and at that time they didn’t know as much as they know now. I mean, you can really do that now. Thirty years, forty years later, it’s...it’s really ripe to develop those kind of classes on...on, you know, history of the Chicano or...or just history of colonization and...and genocide.

And you can look at any war, and look at that. You know, that’s...that’s one of the things that, ah...that, you know, there’s a international conference every year in San Diego. And it’s on domestic violence. And they always have a segment there on, uh, miscegna—genocide and war, you know. And, ah...ah, we...we...that’s a really a key to our history, and maybe even our identity, you know, as Indians, as Mestizo, you know, or...or as Mexicans. Not as Indians, not as, ah, Mestizos or half-Spanish, but as Mexicans. That is our c—Mexican cultural heritage, just like, ah...the slaves, part of their identity comes back from being slaves.

Well, we also have similar-like roots that are reflected in the culture over and over again, you know. We may not even realize it. You know, we may even say it in joking, or (concareno 11:16), or a loving way. Um, but, ah, it...as you’re more assimilated, it means less. But as you’re more, ah...educated in the culture, and it’s part of you, it...and it may mean more than we’re really conscious of. And, ah, to me that’s me that’s interesting. To me, especially coming from...I know I come from that history. I know that, ah, I’m the product or rape. Not me personally, but my family is a product of rape, my...a product of...of not having any rights against...you know, not having rights to...to...to say, “This crime was committed against us,” and the policemen saying, “Sorry, you don’t have any rights here,” you know. Um, the woman story, the migration of women, you know, from Mexico to the United States, being in the United States, especially during the early 1900’s, if you were alone and a si—a single parent, those were...those were hell of a women who really had to...were very vulnerable in that society, very vulnerable.

Because if you were trying to run away from man, and you were married to him, even though you were in Bisby, Arizona, and the guy’s in Mexico, there’s all this letter writing, and if somebody’s looking for you, you are somebody’s husband and so they should know. So you could never run away. You know, how...now we have all kinds of communication. But back then you didn’t really. You just had letters. And still, someone could hunt you down, uh, because you were somebody’s property.

So, all these things interest me. And I think that, ah, they would interest other peoples. And they could be analyzed, in terms of, ah, a, um, political, economic, social, psychological, cultural way. Just there’s so many dynamics. And I’m sure there’ll be a diversity of thought along the way, but they should be explored. And in time we...we would come to say, “You know, we are we. We’re not three, we’re not part this, part that, part this, part that. You know, uh, you’re not real...we won’t be s—oh, you’re not a true Mexican. You know, what kind of Mexican is that?” (? 13:51) to that kind of talk. It’s not funny. It’s not good. It’s not good for us. It’s not good for our kids. Um, and it’s not good for anybody, who—whoever they are. You know, uh, historically, people...children have been rejected because, whatever their mother or father did, whatever race or family they came from, whether they came from this side of the tracks or it’s that side of the tracks, that kind of class mentality is reflected in the culture and it’s never good. But it’s always to somebody’s advantage.

But we use it and it’s not even to our advantage. But we still use it. So it’s like a remnant. I wrote...I wrote a article long time ago that we have these remnants of these col—feudal colonial history that is very reflected in our sexual roles, you know, ah, that really are remnants of, ah...ah, feudalism, you know, being somebody’s property, whether you’re a man or a women, you know, being somebody else’s property. And, uh, there’s nothing so precious about that.
I
words: So [chuckles], I do have to ask you one last thing. And it follows on what you’ve said just now. The last question in our list of questions was, you know, where you think like Chicana feminism is today. When you were extremely active in the movement, before you were sort of pushed out of the academic side of the movement, you know, it’s very clear that Chicana feminism was happening in (15:53 En Quentro Feminine), and newspapers, at conferences. It was being articulated in those spaces and even in the classes that you taught, the early...the groundbreaking classes that you were teaching. What do you think...where do you see it today? Where is it today? Is it in the streets? Is it in conferences? Is it in the academy?

speaker: R
words: Um...I see it more alive outside of the campus than on the campus. But it definitely is on the campus. The reason why I see it more outside of the campuses, that the students, women, young women, are...I don’t know what’s happening in the community. But, you know, like for instance, I meet more high school graduates that already pretty independent, self-sufficient. They’ve gon—they’re...they’ve done a lot of things on their own. They’re so defined. Ah...they had a...um, a high school recruitment there at Cal State Long Beach, and I had bumped into some of the girls. And, uh, this one was, uh, just graduating from high school this year but she was already...she saw in her mind she had some kind of business plan, ah, for, um, advertising. She was mixing graphic arts, and, um, communications, and (kinsinethas 17:36) together. And she already had developed a...a business.

speaker: Um, a lot...uh, some other women...just they’re more...they’re more centered. They’re more independent. Centered meaning independent, you know. So they have had more experience in, um...uh, self, uh, development and doing a lot of things before they even graduate from high school than normal. So they have a sense of self. They have a sense of, uh, what do I want, uh, about the way they wanted to be treated. If there is, ah...bad news somewhere, they don’t want to be there, they’re not going to take it, they just move on. They’ve got...they’ve got things to do, uh...uh, stories to write, and...and...and they’re going forward. And I don’t remember that being that prevalent. But I find that that’s more prevalent. And even those women that I bump into who...you know, at these different conferences, who are the young...the recruits, they may not know what they want to be but they know that they’ve got place—y—things to learn and stories to...And they even know

...like for instance, I met this one woman. She was a history major at UCR. But for whatever reason she decided to be a doctor. She had no background. So she said, “I have to start all over again, take all the sciences.” And I’d say, “How’re you doing in that?” And he says, “Well, it’s been really hard because I don’t understand why, you know, these systems work like this.” So she had no foundation in biology, no fou—foundations in systems theories, or statistics, chemistry. She didn’t know how they were all related. But no problema, she was going to find out. And she was beginning to synthesize it. And I just came along and met her just at the right time, when she was synthesizing it. And she was telling me about it. I was a stranger out of nowhere. You know, I didn’t find that. I...I don’t remember finding that at that time, okay?

So, to me, that’s part of feminism, is, uh...uh, being independent, defining yourself, being comfortable in, um, exploring, ah, something you don’t know, and be comfortable with things you don’t know but the co—uh, confident you’re going to master it, you’re going to find out, and confident that you’re going to find out if you like this or not, and if you don’t, that’s okay because you see yourself accomplishing something, and writing about it, talking about it. Ah, it’s a very exciting...this is just a...I see it more in the women talking, and...and being more self-defined, and independent. That’s the key thing. You know, they’re driving. There’s these little cues.
R
words: You know, just because you see more Chicanos driving is a very, very critical indicator of, uh, their extent of experience in independent decision-making, confidence in their decisions, successful decisions, and having a sense of, “I’m here, I’m going to go there,” you know, “And this is what I think,” and then...and good listeners, but don’t feel the pressure that they have to think the same way somebody else had just finished talking about, you know, “We might want to think about that. We’ll see.” You know. I like that.

speaker: R
words: I like that. So I see that change. Ah...and it’s very healthy. Very healthy. So I don’t know that it’s about more assimilation. I don’t know what that’s about. Maybe there’s more support. There’s more resources out there. Whatever it is, it’s a good thing. On academics, I see things pretty much...there are more women in academia. There are more women promoting gender and sexual issues. I...from what I hear, they have the sa—they’re going through many times the same struggles that I went through. I think the big issue right now in academia is, ah, homosexuality and I think that that’s real intense and very hostile, you know. And so that that hostility needs to be, um, resolved before it goes too far, and, um, mellowed out, and...and mediated, and address the hostility, not just the issue, but the hostility really needs to be a—addressed and seen. It’s like ignoring that there’s a hungry tiger in the room. I mean, you’ve got to millio—there’s a hungry tiger in the room and we’ve go to get it out. How do we do this? So I’m really worried about that.

speaker: And, ah, the...I...I’d say lesbian thought, I haven’t seen too much male gay...um, heard or seen male gay thought. You know, so, um, I can only comment on the lesbian Chicana thought. That is very, um, mind-blowing. I mean, it’s using symbols in a way that I’ve never seen. It’s communicating ideas that I don’t always get. Um, and it’s very thought-provoking. And, ah, I...I really...I’ve only heard a couple, so I really would like to hear a lot more. Because then these symbols, these traditional symbols...like there was a...I just recently saw a presentation on...this woman presented our lady of Guadalupe in different...different poses. And she shares that she’s, ah...gay and the struggle she’s had in coming out, and how all of that is reflected in the (? 24:14) de Guadalupe. Now I, myself, think it’s a long time that we kind of like, ah...well, people are not going to like this but I think it’s long time that we put our lady Guadalupe on the shelf...
R
words: ...and move forward, that the...the...the person that we should be putting forth is your mother, your father, ah, just a woman in general, you know, your sister...us, the contemporary person, ah...and say we are. Okay, we are. And...and we’re proud of it, whatever. Okay. Our lady...but I understand why Our Lady of Guadalupe is so important. As a matter of fact, when she made that presentation, I finally understood why it was so important. Because I always would tell Richard, I’d go, “You know, there was some girl who, ah, was denied tenure because she was a artist and she did, ah, big portrait of our lady of Guadalupe.” And I don’t think there was anything revolutionary about it. It was just a painting. And they felt it wasn’t academic enough. I think that was the...their...their criticism. And I talked to, ah, (Mailie 25:36) and Richard. I go, “Why do we have to still do our lady of Guadalupe? How isn’t there something more substantial that represents today?” And he goes, “Anna, she’s very important. You have to understand, it’s faith and religion.” And I go, “Well, that’s true, I don’t understand.” But when I saw this lady’s – and I’m sorry that I don’t remember her name – but when she presented our lady of Guadalupe, then it was like the nose on my face, and I was very embarrassed. Because it’s about acceptance, about love. It’s about, ah, belonging, you know. It’s about...it really is another way of we are. And, ah, I wish that...I...like I like the (? 26:29 En Quentro) symbol, with a crowd of women, and men, and children. That’s we are, you know, (somos, casomas, somas de a quy 26:34). You know, and that’s it, no ifs or butts. You know, we don’t have to explain. Um, and we’re real.

speaker: But, you know, love, acceptance from a...for our people, or a person who feels rejected, denied, a nonentity, ah, an outcast...I finally got it, you know. And, and, uh...unfortunately, she got a lot of criticism, and so did the students who invited her over because it was...what do you call it, uh...what do you call it when you do something bad that’s really just...sacrilegious? There’s another word for it though.
R
words: Uh, maybe it was blasphemy. But it was all those kinds of words, you know, that...that this woman had committed. And, ah...and they lost the point. You know, this is about acceptance, love. Both sexual love and...and...and, ah, a general love. So there’s that...that’s...that’s...and...and I haven’t really, ah...I don’t...I haven’t really exposed to it all, but I’ve read quite a lot. I don’t always get it because I think it’s, um...it’s...it’s still in the hostile stage, you know. And, uh...uh, so, where it’s hostile there’s always a little self-hate, always, you know, because you’re just projecting out. So, I guess that’s the healing part. It depends on what they’re actually saying. Because I know...used to read Chicano Press and then read all this hostility. And again, that’s again, you know, saying, “Stop it. You know, I hate you for being so...so hostile and cruel.” But also, that’s still inside. Uh, it’s so damaging. Racism, sexism is very damaging. Very damaging. And then, ah, if you’re rejected for whom you are than you...it stunts your development. That’s the end. Does that answer your question?
